questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of intermittent swelling of his left arm and feeling of fullness in his head that is exacerbated by lying down and bending over to tie his shoes. Physical examination shows left-sided facial edema and distention of superficial veins in the neck and left chest wall. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Right heart failure causes backward failure, leading to systemic venous congestion, increased central venous pressure, jugular venous distension (JVD), and peripheral pitting edema. Although this patient does have JVD and edema, the edema caused by right heart failure would be bilateral, because the right heart receives venous blood from both sides of the body via the superior vena cava. This patient has unilateral edema, suggesting that venous return is obstructed upstream from the superior vena cava.

B) INCORRECT:

A cervical rib is usually asymptomatic but can cause lower brachial plexus palsy or compression of the subclavian vessels, as in thoracic outlet syndrome. Compression of the left subclavian vein by a cervical rib could explain this patient's left-sided unilateral arm swelling. However, it would not explain his JVD or facial edema, since the jugular veins would still be able to drain venous blood from his face and neck into the brachiocephalic vein and then into the superior vena cava without obstruction.

C) CORRECT:

This patient likely has brachiocephalic syndrome due to a Pancoast tumor. Predominantly caused by non-small cell lung cancer, these tumors are located in the superior sulcus of the lung, where infiltration of nearby structures causes a recognizable constellation of symptoms. This patient's unilateral facial swelling and head fullness are likely due to jugular venous congestion, while his unilateral arm edema suggests subclavian venous congestion. These vessels merge at the brachiocephalic vein, making it the most likely site of obstruction.

Pancoast tumors can also cause SVC syndrome and Horner syndrome.
Image Description:

Chest, neck, and abdomen (coronal section, ventral view)

The veins depicted here ultimately drain into the superior and the inferior vena cava.

D) INCORRECT:

Subclavian steal syndrome arises due to stenosis of a subclavian artery and manifests with ischemic symptoms, e.g., pain and pallor, in the arm on the affected side. In some cases, neurologic symptoms may occur, including lightheadedness caused by reversed blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery. Although this patient has symptoms affecting only one arm, edema and venous distention indicate a venous rather than arterial obstruction. Moreover, he does not have any ischemic or neurologic symptoms.
Image Description:

Under normal conditions, the subclavian artery distributes blood equally to the arteries in the brain and arms (A). If there is stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery, this leads to hypoperfusion of the upper extremities on the affected side (B). This is compensated by a contralateral circulation, in which there is increased blood flow from the unaffected side to the affected side via the vertebral arteries. As a result, there is hypoperfusion of the vertebrobasilar territory and corresponding central nervous system symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Mediastinal lymphoma, most often Hodgkin lymphoma or primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma, manifests with signs and symptoms of a mediastinal mass (e.g., chest pain, cough, and shortness of breath), B symptoms, and cervical lymphadenopathy, none of which are present here. Mediastinal lymphoma is most likely to occur in the anterior mediastinum, causing compression of the superior vena cava (i.e., SVC syndrome). Since the SVC drains both the right and left brachiocephalic veins, SVC syndrome involves bilateral symptoms, unlike the unilateral symptoms seen in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (a: PA view; b: left lateral view) and CT chest (c: with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with nodular sclerosing Hodgkin lymphoma

The PA radiograph shows an abnormal superior mediastinum that is dense, markedly widened, and lobulated (green overlay). On the lateral radiograph, there is opacification of the retrosternal space, which should normally be a clear area. CT confirms the presence of a large anterior locally invasive mediastinal soft tissue mass (arrows).

Li: liver; LV: left ventricle
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of facial swelling, arm swelling, and distention of neck and chest wall veins is concerning for brachiocephalic syndrome.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with gastroesophageal reflux disease and osteoarthritis is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe, stabbing epigastric pain. For the last 6 months, he has had progressively worsening right knee pain, for which he takes ibuprofen several times a day. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia without ST-segment elevations or depressions. This patient is most likely to have referred pain in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The right arm is not a typical location of referred pain. Although radiation of pain to the left arm is seen in myocardial infarction, the right arm is not a typical location of referred pain in any condition. This patient's risk factors and symptoms are consistent with a perforated peptic ulcer, which typically manifests with referred pain to a different region of the body.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's history of smoking and chronic NSAID use put him at increased risk of developing peptic ulcers. Perforated gastric ulcers can manifest with the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, as seen in this patient, and referred pain to the left shoulder due to irritation of the left hemidiaphragm. Both the phrenic nerve (C3-5), which innervates the diaphragm, and the supraclavicular nerves (C3-4), which innervate the shoulder, share sensory fibers from the C3-4 nerve roots.
Image Description:

Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)

Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

C) INCORRECT:

Periumbilical pain is seen in conditions that cause irritation of the T10 dermatome, such as in the early stages of appendicitis. This patient's risk factors and symptoms are more consistent with a perforated peptic ulcer, which is associated with referred pain in a different region of the body.

D) INCORRECT:

Referred pain to the jaw can occur in a myocardial infarction and is caused by irritation of nerves of the cervical plexus, which innervate the neck and the jaw. Although this patient's smoking history is a risk factor for coronary artery disease, his normal ECG makes this diagnosis less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Referred pain to the groin can occur in conditions that cause irritation to the L1 dermatome, including nephrolithiasis, hip arthritis, and testicular pathology. This patients risk factors and symptoms are more consistent with a perforated peptic ulcer, which is associated with referred pain to a different region of the body.
questions.hint: This patient has multiple risk factors for peptic ulcer disease, including smoking, NSAID use, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. The sudden onset of pain is concerning for a perforated peptic ulcer.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations. She has a history of recurrent episodes of joint pain and fever during childhood. She emigrated from India with her parents when she was 10 years old. Cardiac examination shows an opening snap followed by a late diastolic rumble, which is best heard at the fifth intercostal space in the left midclavicular line. This patient is at greatest risk for compression of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The trachea terminates by bifurcating into the right and left bronchi superior to the left atrium. Therefore, cardiac compression of the trachea is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The thoracic duct lies in the posterior mediastinum and is separated from the heart by the descending thoracic aorta and the esophagus. It is therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement.

C) INCORRECT:

The vagus nerves lie posterior to the hila of the lungs bilaterally. They are therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement. In rare cases, compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve by a significantly enlarged left atrium may occur in patients with chronic mitral stenosis. Patients may then present with hoarseness of voice.

D) INCORRECT:

The hemiazygos vein lies in the posterior mediastinum, which is separated from the heart by the descending thoracic aorta and the esophagus. It is therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement.

E) CORRECT:

Because the posterior mediastinal portion of the esophagus lies just behind the left atrium, it is at risk of being compressed and/or displaced by an enlarged left atrium. Left atrial enlargement due to increased left atrial pressure can develop in patients with chronic mitral stenosis, although this occurs very rarely.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur is characteristic of mitral stenosis, which, given her immigration history and recurrent fever and joint pain, is most likely secondary to rheumatic fever. Untreated chronic mitral stenosis results in left atrium dilation, which can compress adjacent structures.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of intractable hiccups and shortness of breath on exertion. He also has a 1-month history of left shoulder pain. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds at the left lung base. An x-ray of the chest shows a 3-cm perihilar mass and elevation of the left hemidiaphragm. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by injury to a nerve that also innervates which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The phrenic nerve could be compressed by a mediastinal lung tumor, a diagnosis of high clinical suspicion in this patient, given his smoking history and the perihilar mass seen on imaging. Each phrenic nerve provides motor and sensory supply to the ipsilateral hemidiaphragm as well as sensory supply to the fibrous pericardium and the mediastinal and diaphragmatic pleura. Pericarditis pain is often referred to the shoulder due to common innervation via the phrenic nerve.

The phrenic nerve originates from the C3â€“C5 nerve roots. Remember: â€œC-three, four, five keeps the diaphragm alive!â€

B) INCORRECT:

The serratus anterior muscle is innervated by the long thoracic nerve that arises from the C5â€“C7 nerve roots. Damage to this nerve would cause winging of the scapula, not elevation of the hemidiaphragm as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The vocal cords are innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Vocal cord palsies can present with hoarseness, dyspnea, weak cough, and recurrent aspiration. An elevated hemidiaphragm, hiccups, and shoulder pain would not be seen.

D) INCORRECT:

The ciliary muscle is innervated by the sympathetic trunks through the stellate ganglion. Although an apical lung tumor can cause compression of the sympathetic trunks (Horner syndrome), a mediastinal lung tumor, as seen here, could not.

E) INCORRECT:

The C8â€“T1 dermatome is innervated by the lower part of the brachial plexus. While the brachial plexus may be disrupted by apical lung tumors, potentially resulting in shoulder pain, damage to this structure would not result in an elevated hemidiaphragm, cough, or hiccups.

F) INCORRECT:

The visceral pleura is innervated by the vagus nerve and sympathetic nerves, not the phrenic nerve. Furthermore, both the lung parenchyma and visceral pleura are insensitive to most painful stimuli, those mediated by stretch fibers being the exception. As a result, visceral pleuritic pain tends to be vague and poorly localized.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms (hiccups, dyspnea, shoulder pain, elevated hemidiaphragm) suggest compression of the phrenic nerve, which arises from the C3â€“C5 nerve roots.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She reports that she feels well. Upon questioning, she mentions that she has had an occasional dry cough and recurrent hoarseness over the past 6 months. She does not smoke and has not lost weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. An x-ray of the chest shows a mass that projects across the right hilum. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal cancer often manifests as a middle and/or posterior mediastinal mass. Affected patients typically present with dysphagia and weight loss; hoarseness would be uncommon. In addition, esophageal cancer usually manifests in middle to late adulthood (45â€“75 years old) rather than young adulthood.

B) INCORRECT:

Although a thymoma may manifest with cough due to mass effect, it develops in the anterior mediastinum. This patient's signs are confined to the posterior mediastinum.

C) CORRECT:

Neurogenic tumors (e.g., neurofibromas and schwannomas) account for the majority of posterior mediastinal masses (âˆ¼ 60%). Intrathoracic neurofibromas usually manifest in young adults (20â€“30 years), typically with chest pain caused by mass effect upon the chest wall. Although neurofibromas are benign, large masses can cause a dry cough (due to compression of the lung), hoarseness (due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve), or dysphagia (due to compression of the vagus nerve). As in this case, constitutional symptoms (i.e., fever and weight loss) are usually absent and laboratory studies are typically normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Teratomas are benign germ cell tumors that are usually asymptomatic but can cause cough due to mass effect. Unlike here, they are generally found in the anterior mediastinum and have CT findings of a heterogeneous mass containing multiple tissue types (e.g., fat, fluid, bone).

E) INCORRECT:

Intrathoracic cardiovascular structural anomalies (e.g., aortic aneurysm, pulmonary artery aneurysm, or vascular ring) usually manifest as masses in the middle and/or posterior mediastinum. Aortic aneurysm usually manifests as left-sided masses, not the right-sided mass seen in this case. In addition, while aortic aneurysms are better visualized on contrast-enhanced chest CT, the mass in this patient is clearly visualized as a separate entity from the intrathoracic aorta.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows that the mass is located in the posterior mediastinum.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after falling from a height of 3 feet onto a sharp metal fence pole. He is unconscious. Physical examination shows a wound on the upper margin of the right clavicle in the parasternal line that is 3-cm-deep. Which of the following is the most likely result of this patient's injury?

choices.text: Rotator cuff tear due to supraspinatus muscle injury
Trapezius muscle paresis due to spinal accessory nerve injury
Hemothorax due to azygos vein injury
Chylothorax due to thoracic duct injury
Traumatic aneurysm due to internal carotid artery injury

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The supraspinatus muscle is part of the rotator cuff, which stabilizes the shoulder joint. It runs from the superior portion of the scapula to the greater tubercle of the humerus. Because this patient's wound is on the upper margin of the right clavicle, injury of the supraspinatus muscle is unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

The pleural membrane covering the apex of the superior lobe of the lung extends approx. 2.5 cm above the medial end of the clavicle. A penetrating injury to the supraclavicular parasternal region, like the one sustained by this patient, can pierce the parietal pleural membrane, permitting air to enter the pleural space and causing an ipsilateral pneumothorax.
Image Description:

Interpretation of a chest x-ray typically begins with a comparison of variations in radiolucency between the apical, upper, middle, and lower zones of the lung.

This approach allows for only a rough localization of potential pathologies because an opacity projecting onto the middle zone can affect either the middle or the lower lobe (they overlap in AP and PA views).

C) INCORRECT:

The spinal accessory nerve exits the skull through the jugular foramen and sends a branch to the sternocleidomastoid muscle 3 cm below the mastoid process before entering the posterior triangle of the neck to innervate the trapezius muscle. Spinal accessory nerve injury resulting in trapezius (and sternocleidomastoid) paralysis would be expected if there were an injury to the upper aspect of the posterior triangle of the neck.

D) INCORRECT:

Azygos vein injury would cause hemothorax. However, the azygos vein drains into the superior vena cava at the level of the 4th thoracic vertebra (T4). It does not extend into the supraclavicular space and would therefore not be susceptible to injury in a penetrating trauma to the right supraclavicular space.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the thoracic duct would cause chylothorax. The thoracic duct extends into the left supraclavicular space just before it drains into the venous system at the junction of the left subclavian and internal jugular vein. As this patient has sustained an injury to the right supraclavicular space, his thoracic duct would not be injured.

F) INCORRECT:

The internal carotid artery (ICA) usually arises from the common carotid artery at the level of the fourth cervical vertebra (C4). A traumatic aneurysm of the ICA would therefore be expected secondary to a neck injury at or above the C4 level.
questions.hint: This condition can also be caused by improper placement of a central venous catheter.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department because of lightheadedness over the past 2 hours. He reports that he has had similar episodes of lightheadedness and palpitations over the past 3 days. His only medication is metformin. His pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular. An ECG shows a variable R-R interval and absence of P waves. The patient undergoes transesophageal echocardiography. During the procedure, the tip of the ultrasound probe is angled posteriorly within the esophagus. This view is most helpful for evaluating which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Thrombus in the left pulmonary artery
Thrombus in the left ventricular apex
Tumor in the right main bronchus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The esophagus lies posterior to the right pulmonary artery, which can be seen in the anterior view on a TEE. However, the left pulmonary artery is hardly visible in any view on TEE.

B) INCORRECT:

A tumor in the left atrium, e.g., left atrial myxoma, can be visualized well on TEE, but only when the probe is rotated anteriorly in the mid-esophagus. The left atrium, right atrium, and interatrial septum can be seen in the anterior view.

C) CORRECT:

The upper esophagus lies posterior to the trachea and anterior to the vertebral column. Below the bifurcation of the trachea, the descending aorta lies posterior to the lower esophagus. An aneurysm of the descending aorta can, therefore, be visualized well on transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) through an ultrasound probe that is angled posteriorly within the esophagus.
Image Description:

Esophagus and surrounding structures (anterior view)

The esophagus begins at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It first descends posterior to the trachea, and then posterior to the heart. At the level of the 4th thoracic vertebra, the aorta runs adjacent to the esophagus, pushing it slightly to the right. The esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra and ends at the stomach after a brief stretch within the peritoneum.

The upper part of the trachea, lungs, and heart are not shown for clarity.

D) INCORRECT:

A thrombus in the left ventricular apex can be visualized well on transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) because of the proximity of the ventricular apex to the anterior chest wall. While a TEE allows for better imaging quality when evaluating the cardiac structures that lie in close proximity to the esophagus, more anterior structures such as the left ventricular apex would not be seen well.

E) INCORRECT:

The esophagus lies posterior to the trachea and left mainstem bronchus. These structures could be visualized in the anterior view on a TEE, but the right main bronchus would not be seen. A chest x-ray or CT imaging of the chest is indicated if a bronchial tumor is suspected.
questions.hint: Other structures lying posterior and in close proximity to the esophagus include the thoracic duct and azygos vein.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a coworker for an injury sustained at work. He works in construction and accidentally shot himself in the chest with a nail gun. Physical examination shows a bleeding wound in the left hemithorax at the level of the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?

choices.text: Left middle lobe of the lung
Left upper lobe of the lung
Left lower lobe of the lung

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unlike the right lung, the left lung has no middle lobe. The left lung has a sub-segment, the lingula of the left lung, which is thought to be a remnant of the middle lobe.

B) INCORRECT:

While the right atrium of the heart is located between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space, it is mainly located posterior to the sternum. It is not located in the left hemithorax, where this patient's injury occurred.

C) INCORRECT:

The superior vena cava is located in the superior mediastinum slightly lateral to the right sternal border between the 1st and 3rd intercostal space. It is not located in the left hemithorax, where this patient's injury occurred.

D) INCORRECT:

The inferior vena cava is located below the 4th intercostal space just to the right of the sternum. It is not located in the left hemithorax, where this patient's injury occurred.

E) INCORRECT:

The left atrium of the heart is located between the 2nd and 3rd intercostal space slightly lateral to the left sternal border, which is superior and medial to the point of injury in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

The left upper lobe of the lung is anterior to the left lower lobe with boundaries extending from above the first rib to about the 6th intercostal space along the midclavicular line. Thus, a penetrating wound in the 4th intercostal space of the anterior left chest will most likely involve the left upper lobe.
Image Description:

ICS: intercostal space

G) INCORRECT:

The left lower lobe of the lung primarily occupies the posterior and lower hemithorax and approaches the anterior hemithorax below the 4th intercostal space. However, this patient's wound is in the 4th intercostal space of the anterior left chest.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of difficulty swallowing and a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows an exophytic mass in the distal third of the esophagus. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen shows a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient is scheduled for surgical resection of the tumor. During the procedure, the surgeon damages a structure that passes through the diaphragm along with the esophagus at the level of the tenth thoracic vertebra (T10). Which of the following structures was most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) exits the thoracic cavity together with the esophagus through the esophageal hiatus, a diaphragmatic aperture at the level of T10, and innervates the smooth muscle cells of the digestive tract. Periesophageal vagus nerve injury, which may occur during thoracic or gastric surgery, typically manifests with delayed gastric emptying. Other symptoms of vagus nerve injury depend on the level at which the lesion is located and include loss of the gag reflex, vocal cord paralysis (manifesting as hoarseness), and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., impaired heart rate variability).

Further causes of vagus nerve injury include diabetic neuropathy, trauma, and inflammation.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the inferior vena cava can be damaged during thoracic surgery, it enters the thoracic cavity through the caval hiatus, a diaphragmatic aperture at the level of the eighth thoracic vertebra (T8).

C) INCORRECT:

Although the thoracic duct can be damaged during thoracic surgery, it enters the thoracic cavity through the aortic hiatus, a diaphragmatic aperture at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra (T12).

D) INCORRECT:

Although the aorta can be damaged during thoracic surgery, it exits the thoracic cavity through the aortic hiatus, a diaphragmatic aperture at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra (T12).

E) INCORRECT:

Although the right phrenic nerve can be damaged during thoracic surgery, it exits the thoracic cavity through the caval hiatus, a diaphragmatic aperture at the level of the eighth thoracic vertebra (T8).

F) INCORRECT:

Although the azygos vein can be damaged during thoracic surgery, it enters the thoracic cavity through the aortic hiatus, a diaphragmatic aperture at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra (T12).
questions.hint: Damage to this structure may cause gastroparesis.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 38 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: â€œI'm gasping for breath.â€
History of Present Illness:

1-month history of progressively worsening breathlessness and nonproductive cough


dyspnea was initially only present during exercise but is now also present at rest 
increasing difficulty swallowing solid food for the past 3 weeks


headache and dizziness for the past week

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory 
Psychosocial History:
does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages
Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.8Â°C(98.2Â°F)
89/min
24/min
122/73 mm Hg
95% on RA
164 cm(5 ft 5 in)
82 kg(180 lb)
30.5 kg/m2




Appearance: in respiratory distress; uses accessory muscles of respiration; coughs frequently
Skin: no rash
HEENT: normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; thyroid gland is normal in size with no mass or tenderness; mild facial plethora
Neck: jugular venous distention 
Pulmonary: expiratory stridor
Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated, normoactive bowel sounds
Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits

Diagnostic Studies

chest x-ray: widened upper mediastinum on PA view and an obscured retrosternal airspace on lateral view
chest CT: bulky soft tissue mass with cystic changes in the anterior and superior mediastinum 
direct laryngoscopy: vocal cords are symmetrical and move during attempted phonation; no polyps or nodules


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal cancer manifests with dysphagia but an esophageal pathology would be visible in the posterior mediastinum, not the anterior compartment.

B) INCORRECT:

Ortner syndrome is vocal cord palsy caused by compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve in the mediastinum. The underlying pathologies include a large left atrium or aortic aneurysm, which can also cause dysphagia due to esophageal compression. This patient does not have laryngoscopic findings of vocal cord palsy. Additionally, the heart is located in the middle mediastinum, while the aorta is located in the middle, superior, and posterior mediastinum. An anterior mediastinal mass would not be expected with a large atrium or aortic aneurysm.

C) INCORRECT:

A mediastinal neuroblastoma arises from the paravertebral ganglia and is usually located in the posterior mediastinum, not the anterior and superior compartments. Moreover, neuroblastoma is very rare in adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial tumors can cause cough and respiratory distress as a result of bronchial obstruction, but they typically manifest with recurrent pneumonia, hemoptysis, and, in rare cases, symptoms of carcinoid syndrome. Moreover, the majority of carcinoid tumors appear on imaging as focal, well-defined round lesions, as opposed to a large mediastinal mass with cystic changes.

E) CORRECT:

Mediastinal lymphomas, such as nodular sclerosing Hodgkin lymphomas or primary mediastinal large B-cell lymphomas, appear on imaging as bulky, soft tissue masses with cystic changes. Approx. 50% of patients do not present with B-symptoms. Although mediastinal lymphomas can arise from any mediastinal compartment, airway compression is most commonly associated with superior, anterior, or middle mediastinal masses. Masses that cause superior vena cava syndrome are usually located in the anterior or middle compartments. Esophageal compression typically occurs with superior, middle, or posterior mediastinal masses. While thymoma may also cause anterior and superior mediastinal masses, it usually grows slowly (over several years), in contrast to the rapid development of progressive symptoms in this patient, which is consistent with lymphoma.

See â€œCompartments of the mediastinumâ€ table.
questions.hint: This patient has features of airway obstruction (cough, stridor, dyspnea), esophageal obstruction (dysphagia), and superior vena cava syndrome (jugular venous distention, headache) as a result of a mediastinal mass.

questions.text: You are seeing a 56-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after falling from a height of 3 feet onto a sharp metal fence pole. He is unconscious. On examination, there is a 3-cm-deep wound at the upper margin of the right clavicle in the parasternal line. Which one of the following is the most likely result of this injury?

choices.text: Hemothorax due to azygos vein injury.
Trapezius muscle paresis due to spinal accessory nerve injury.
Traumatic aneurysm due to internal carotid artery injury.
Chylothorax due to thoracic duct injury.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azygos vein injury would cause hemothorax. However, the azygos vein drains into the superior vena cava at the level of the 4th thoracic vertebra (T4). It does not extend into the supraclavicular space and would therefore not be susceptible to injury in a penetrating trauma to the right supraclavicular space.

B) INCORRECT:

The spinal accessory nerve exits the skull through the jugular foramen and sends a branch to the sternocleidomastoid muscle 3 cm below the mastoid process before entering the posterior triangle of the neck to innervate the trapezius muscle. Spinal accessory nerve injury resulting in trapezius (and sternocleidomastoid) paralysis would be expected if there were an injury to the upper aspect of the posterior triangle of the neck.

C) INCORRECT:

The internal carotid artery (ICA) usually arises from the common carotid artery at the level of the fourth cervical vertebra (C4). A traumatic aneurysm of the ICA would therefore be expected secondary to a neck injury at or above the C4 level.

D) INCORRECT:

Injury to the thoracic duct would cause chylothorax. The thoracic duct extends into the left supraclavicular space just before it drains into the venous system at the junction of the left subclavian and internal jugular vein. As this patient has sustained an injury to the right supraclavicular space, his thoracic duct would not be injured.

E) CORRECT:

The pleural membrane covering the apex of the superior lobe of the lung extends approximately 2.5 cm above the medial end of the clavicle. A penetrating injury to the supraclavicular parasternal region, like the one sustained by this patient, can pierce the parietal pleural membrane, permitting air to enter the pleural space and causing an ipsilateral pneumothorax.

Key learning point: A penetrating injury above the clavicle near the parasternal line can puncture the pleura, allowing air into the pleural space and causing a pneumothorax.
Image Description:

Interpretation of a chest x-ray typically begins with a comparison of variations in radiolucency between the apical, upper, middle, and lower zones of the lung.

This approach allows for only a rough localization of potential pathologies because an opacity projecting onto the middle zone can affect either the middle or the lower lobe (they overlap in AP and PA views).
questions.hint: This condition can also be caused by improper placement of a central venous catheter.
